definition[0]: if a price, level etc comes down, it gets lower
example[0]: It looks as if interest rates will come down again this month.
example[1]: He’s asking £5,000, but he may be willing to come down to £4,800.
definition[2]: if someone comes down to a place, they travel south to the place where you are
example[2]: Why don’t you come down for the weekend sometime?
example[3]: Are you coming down to Knoxville for Christmas?
example[4]: A lot of trees came down in the storm.
example[5]: We were still out in the fields when the rain started coming down.
definition[4]: to decide to support someone or something
example[6]: The committee came down in favour of making the information public.
definition[5]: to start to feel normal again after you have been feeling very happy and excited
example[7]: He was on a real high all last week and he’s only just come down.
definition[6]: to stop feeling the effects of a strong drug
example[8]: When I came down, I remembered with horror some of the things I’d said.
definition[7]: to leave a university after completing a period of study
